literal: A sore spot.
meaning: A matter that easily upsets one or about which one is sensitive; something that causes anxiety.
equivalents: A sore/tender spot; a touchy subject

literal: To be afraid of one’s own shadow.
meaning: To be unreasonably nervous due to groundless and trivial fears.
equivalents: To be afraid of one’s own shadow

literal: To take someone under one’s little wing.
meaning: To give someone every care and attention; ti put someone under one’s protection.
equivalents: To take someone under one’s wing

literal: To be on a friendly foot with someone.
meaning: To be on intimate or friendly terms with someone.
equivalents: To be on a good/friendly footing with someone

literal: To be in the seventh heaven.
meaning: To be overfilled with joy, to be supremely happy or satisfied.
equivalents: To tread/walk on air; to be in seventh heaven

literal: To hammer something into someone’s head.
meaning: To make something completely understood by emphatic repetition; to keep reiterating something to make it stick in someone’s mind.
equivalents: To hammer/drive something into someone’s head

literal: To drive a wedge between two groups of people or two individuals.
meaning: To cause a breach or separation, to split apart; to make people quarrel.
equivalents: To drive a wedge

literal: It is whirling on someone’s tongue.
meaning: On the verge of being uttered; something at the back of one’s mind one wants to say but which is not quite within recall of memory.
equivalents: To be on the tip of one’s tongue

literal: To weigh one’s words.
meaning: To choose or use one’s words with deliberation; to give something a comprehensive evaluation.
equivalents: To weigh one’s words

literal: To take the bull by the horns.
meaning: To take up a matter vigorously and promptly getting directly to its essence.
equivalents: To take the bull by the horns

literal: To take someone or something with one’s bare hands.
meaning: To seize, to take possession of someone or something without much difficulty, without making special effort.
equivalents: Without a hand’s turn; with one’s bare hands

literal: To see through someone.
meaning: To know someone well; to be well aware of someone’s thoughts and intentions.
equivalents: To know someone inside out; to see through someone; to read someone like a book

literal: To be hanging on a hair
meaning: To be in a perilous state
equivalents: To hang by a thread; to hang by a single hair

literal: To drive someone into the dye.
meaning: To cause someone to blush from embarrassment.
equivalents: To put someone to the blush

literal: To get into the rut.
meaning: To return to one’s habitual way of life; to settle down into an ordinary way of life; to get back into one’s routine; to return to normal.
equivalents: To get into a groove

literal: To enter into one’s role.
meaning: To become securely and comfortably settled in a new job, position, occupation.
equivalents: To begin to feel one’s feet; to enter into one’s role

literal: One’s hair stands on end.
meaning: One is struck with extreme horror.
equivalents: One’s hair stands on end

literal: To write a new page into something
meaning: To make a discovery; to do something outstanding, prominent in some field.
equivalents: To add a fresh page to something

literal: To put sticks in the wheels.
meaning: To deliberately interfere with the execution of a plan, operation, etc.
equivalents: To put a spoke in someone’s wheel; to throw a spanner in the works; to throw monkey wrenches in the machinery

head_ru: ВЫБИВАТЬ у кого-либо ПОЧВУ ИЗ-ПОД НОГ
literal: To knock the ground from under someone’s feet.
meaning: To deprive someone of his position or role in society; to undermine someone’s confidence in something completely; to disturb someone’s peace of mind.
equivalents: To cut the ground from under someone’s feet; to take the wind out of someone’s sails

literal: To kick someone out of the rut.
meaning: To upset someone’s routine; to unsettle someone.
equivalents: To get someone out of the groove

literal: To throw something out of one’s head.
meaning: To cause to forget; to dismiss from one’s mind; to give up the idea.
equivalents: To put something out of one’s head.

literal: To come out of one’s swaddling-clothes
meaning: To grow up, to become adult, to be on one’s own.
equivalents: To be out of swaddling-clothes

literal: To tear something out with root.
meaning: To destroy something completely; to eradicate, to extirpate, to uproot something.
equivalents: To root something out.

literal: One’s head is going round.
meaning: Someone has a lot to do, is in a state of bewilderment or confusion being worn out with troubles and worry.
equivalents: One’s head is spinning; one’s head is in a whirl; one’s head is going round and round

literal: To divide the skin of an unkilled bear.
meaning: To anticipate too confidently the possession of something that one may never receive; to make plans which depend on events that may not happen.
equivalents: To count one’s chickens before they are hatched; to sell the bear’s skin before one has caught the bear

literal: To keep oneself in one’s hands.
meaning: To restrain oneself; to preserve one’s control.
equivalents: To hold/keep oneself in check; to keep oneself in hand.

literal: To hold one’s tongue behind one’s teeth.
meaning: To keep silent, not to blab; to be cautious in what one says.
equivalents: To hold one’s tongue; to keep one’s breath to cool one’s porridge

literal: To hold to the shade.
meaning: To behave so as to remain unnoticed.
equivalents: To stay in the background.

literal: A long tongue.
meaning: Talkative, unable to hold one’s tongue; a blabber.
equivalents: To have a long tongue; to wag one’s tongue.

literal: To get from under the ground.
meaning: To get something no matter how difficult.
equivalents: To go to the end of the earth to get something.

literal: To come to someone’s ears.
meaning: To become known to someone.
equivalents: To reach someone’s ears.

literal: One shakes like an aspen leaf.
meaning: One trembles violently (usually with excitement or fear).
equivalents: To shake/quake like an aspen leaf.

literal: To lift up one’s nose.
meaning: To act in a superior and affected manner; to become puffed up, conceited.
equivalents: To turn up one’s nose; to put on airs; to cock one’s nose.

literal: To cast a line.
meaning: To make an indirect reference to something in order to find out more about it; to drop a hint by way of suggestion.
equivalents: To put a line out; to put forth/send out a feeler.

literal: To close one’s eyes to something.
meaning: To ignore, deliberately not to pay attention to or recognize something (especially, improper conduct).
equivalents: To close/shut one’s eyes to something; to wink at something.

literal: To sweep over one’s traces.
meaning: To destroy something that can be used as evidence; to conceal one’s movements or activities.
equivalents: To cover up one’s tracks/traces.

literal: To stick someone behind one’s belt.
meaning: To surpass, to outstrip, to outdo someone.
equivalents: To outshine someone; to knock someone into a cocked hat.

literal: The golden middle.
meaning: The safe, prudent way between extremes; the principle of moderation.
equivalents: The golden mean.

literal: A golden bottom.
meaning: An inexhaustible source of wealth.
equivalents: A gold mine.

literal: To play the first violin.
meaning: To play a leading role in some undertaking.
equivalents: To play first fiddle

literal: To play with fire.
meaning: To trifle with something likely to prove dangerous without considering the consequences.
equivalents: To play with edge-tools; to play with fire

literal: To go against the stream.
meaning: To act against the general trend of thought, opinion, custom, etc.
equivalents: To go against the tide/current/stream.

literal: To pour out one’s soul.
meaning: To relieve one’s mind by talking about one’s troubles.
equivalents: To unbosom oneself; to unburden one’s heart; to bare one’s heart/soul.

literal: To measure someone with one’s glance.
meaning: To examine someone closely from head to toe.
equivalents: To look someone up and down; to measure someone with one’s eye.

literal: To have weight.
meaning: To be highly influential or important.
equivalents: To carry a lot of weight

literal: To look for a needle in a bundle of hay.
meaning: To look for something or someone virtually impossible to find.
equivalents: To look for a needle in a haystack

literal: To drink the bowl to the bottom.
meaning: To experience ordeals, hardships, sorrows, misfortunes in full measure.
equivalents: To drink /drain the cup (of bitterness, sorrow, etc.) to the dregs.

literal: As if the wind blew it away.
meaning: Someone or something has rapidly and mysteriously disappeared without a trace.
equivalents: To vanish into thin air.

literal: Like a thunder-clap out of a clear sky.
meaning: Suddenly, unexpectedly (said of a sudden and surprising event generally of an unpleasant nature).
equivalents: Like a bolt from the blue/out of a clear sky.

literal: To slide downhill
meaning: To deteriorate, to decline, to become worse.
equivalents: To go downhill

literal: A corner-stone.
meaning: Something indispensable, essential, of primary importance; a fundamental idea.
equivalents: A corner-stone.

literal: Red as a lobster.
meaning: Red-faced; flushed with anger or embarrassment.
equivalents: Red as a lobster.

literal: To shed crocodile tears.
meaning: To complain hypocritically; to show insincere, false sorrow.
equivalents: To shed crocodile tears

literal: To break one’s head over something.
meaning: To think hard, especially on a difficult problem.
equivalents: To rack/cudgel one’s brains over something; to break one’s head over something.

literal: To break spears.
meaning: To fight for something; to argue heatedly.
equivalents: To break a lance with someone over something; to cross swords.

literal: To break through an open door.
meaning: To assert or try to prove something already well-known and undisputed.
equivalents: To force at/knock at an open door.

literal: Little ants run along one’s back.
meaning: One feels shivery due to fear, horror, or nervous excitement.
equivalents: To give one the creeps; to make one’s flesh creep; to feel chills run up and down one’s spine.

literal: He/she wouldn’t hurt a fly.
meaning: He/she is meek, timid, gentle, kind.
equivalents: He wouldn’t hurt, harm a fly; he won’t say ’boo’ to a goose.

literal: To call things by their names.
meaning: To speak frankly, plainly or bluntly.
equivalents: To call things by their right/proper names; to call a spade a spade.

literal: To stick labels on someone or something.
meaning: To give a standard or stereotyped estimation of someone or something (usually of a negative nature).
equivalents: To pin a label on someone.

literal: Not to see the wood beyond the trees.
meaning: To be unable to get a clear view of the whole because of too many details.
equivalents: To be unable to see the forest/wood for the trees

literal: To be unable to tie two words together
meaning: To be unable to formulate one’s ideas or express one’s thoughts; to be incoherent
equivalents: He can’t put two words together

literal: To find oneself between two fires.
meaning: To be or find oneself between two equally serious evils or dangers, between equally unpleasant alternatives, in a perplexing situation; to be attacked from two directions; to be criticized from both sides.
equivalents: Between the devil and the deep blue sea; between two fires

literal: To pour cold water over someone.
meaning: To disparage someone, to discourage someone’s enthusiasm; to damp someone’s ardour; to throw someone into confusion.
equivalents: To throw/ pour cold water on/over someone.

literal: To open someone’s eyes to someone or something
meaning: To enable one to understand, to cause one be aware of or to realise a fact, truth, reality to which one had been blind.
equivalents: To open someone’s eyes to something or someone

literal: To pay someone back in the same coin.
meaning: To act by using on an opponent the same methods he employed against one; to return like for like; to retaliate.
equivalents: To pay one back in his own coin; to pay/answer back in kind

literal: To go down stream
meaning: To do or think as most people do; to allow one’s actions and principles to be guided solely by the prevailing trend; to be carried away by the course of events.
equivalents: To go/ swim with the stream/current; to follow the crowd.

literal: To be in someone else’s hide.
meaning: To be in the same unpleasant position or adverse circumstances as someone else.
equivalents: To be in someone’s shoes/skin

literal: To turn one’s tail between one’s legs
meaning: To become more cautious, circumspect; to cease boasting; to become less self-assured.
equivalents: To have/put one’s tail between one’s legs; to sing small

literal: To add oil to the fire.
meaning: To act or speak in such a way as to increase the existing passion or excitement; to aggravate the trouble; to make a bad matter worse.
equivalents: To add fuel to the fire

literal: Under one’s nose.
meaning: Directly in front of one; in plain view; in one’s presence.
equivalents: Near at hand; under someone’s very nose; before someone’s face

literal: To clip someone’s wings
meaning: To limit one’s movements, activities; to hamper one’s freedom of action; to destroy one’s self- confidence; to undermine one’s power or ability to do something.
equivalents: To clip/cut someone’s wings/claws

literal: To reap the fruits
meaning: To experience the results of one’s actions, deeds, behaviour.
equivalents: To reap the fruits of something.

literal: With one’s hand on one’s heart.
meaning: To say something quite frankly, candidly, sincerely.
equivalents: To say something with one’s hand upon one’s heart, open-heartedly

literal: They can be counted on one’s fingers.
meaning: Very few; in small quantities.
equivalents: You can count them on your fingers

literal: To put someone in his place
meaning: To snub a person who is overstepping his bounds; to check someone’s presumption
equivalents: To put someone in his place. To rest on one’s laurels

literal: To take something in one’s hands
meaning: To appropriate, to seize, to take possession of.
equivalents: To lay one’s hands on something

literal: A trial ball.
meaning: An approach or device (usually by making discreet inquiries) used to clarify a situation or test the opinions or feelings of others.
equivalents: A trial balloon; a feeler

literal: To go through fire and water
meaning: To go through a great deal in life; to encounter or face | the greatest dangers or hardest experiences; to endure perils of all kinds
equivalents: To go through fire and water; to go through the mill

literal: To throw dust in someone’s eyes
meaning: To make a false impression; to try to impress people with one’s superiority, to display oneself; to act in an ostentatious manner
equivalents: To put on airs; to cut a dash; to throw dust in someone’s eyes

literal: To untie someone’s hands.
meaning: To give someone freedom of action, choice or judgement in a matter.
equivalents: To give someone a free hand; to untie someone’s hands.

literal: To untie one’s tongue
meaning: To begin to talk a lot; to speak after having remained silent.
equivalents: To loosen one’s tongue; to find one’s tongue’s tongue.

literal: To tear one’s hair.
meaning: To be desperate; to be distressed; to grieve.
equivalents: To tear one’s hair.

literal: To be born under a lucky star.
meaning: To be always lucky, successful, happy
equivalents: To always fall on one’s feet; to be born under a lucky star

literal: To be hewing down a bough on which you are sitting.
meaning: To act in such a way as to do oneself harm.
equivalents: To cut one’s own throat; to saw off the bough on which one is sitting

literal: One’s hands are itching.
meaning: Someone is anxious to do something.
equivalents: One’s fingers/hands itch to do something.

literal: To throw off the mask.
meaning: To show one’s true self, one’s true character and intentions.
equivalents: To throw off the mask

literal: To bring the ends together.
meaning: With great effort or difficulty to balance one’s income with one’s expenditures; to manage with one’s resources.
equivalents: To make both ends meet.

literal: To shift mountains.
meaning: To do something important which calls for great effort.
equivalents: To move mountains.

head_ru: СВЯЗАТЬ кого-либо ПО РУКАМ И НОГАМ
transliteration: To tie someone’s hands and feet
literal: hands and feet.
meaning: To deprive someone of the possibility to act freely; to completely restrain someone’s activities by conditions or rules.
equivalents: To bind/tie someone hand and foot

literal: To burn the ships /bridges.
meaning: To take an irrevocable step; to do something that makes it impossible to retreat, to change one’s plans, etc.
equivalents: To burn one’s boats/bridges.

literal: To glide on the surface.
meaning: To deal with a subject only superficially; to pay attention to outward appearances without going to the root of the matter.
equivalents: To skim the surface of something never to go below the surface.

literal: With a light heart.
meaning: Free from sorrow, discomfort, anxiety, misgivings.
equivalents: With a light heart.

literal: To break the ice.
meaning: To put an end to formality, stiffness or shyness in one’s relations with people; to make the first step; to mark the beginning; to cause any matter to start moving.
equivalents: To start the ball rolling; to break the ice

literal: One has fallen from the moon.
meaning: Someone is puzzled; someone doesn’t understand what is evident to everyone.
equivalents: As if he were born yesterday; to fall from the moon.

literal: To look through one’s fingers.
meaning: To purposely avoid seeing; to deliberately ignore a piece of misconduct or a transgression; to refuse to observe something; to connive at; to wink at.
equivalents: To make light of; to turn a blind eye to; to look the other way; to look through one’s fingers.

literal: To look through rose-coloured glasses.
meaning: Not to see a person’s shortcomings: to take too optimistic a view of someone or something.
equivalents: To view/look through rose coloured-glasses

literal: To take off one’s hat before someone.
meaning: To express respect, admiration for a person’s achievements.
equivalents: To take off one’s hat to someone

literal: To stick one’s nose into something.
meaning: To meddle in or interfere with other people’s affairs; to intrude where one is not wanted.
equivalents: To poke / stick one’s nose into something

literal: To stand up on one’s hind legs.
meaning: To resist; to protest; to display stubbornness.
equivalents: To rear up; to stand up on one’s hind legs

literal: To build something on sand.
meaning: To make plans, organise a scheme, etc., on an insecure foundation.
equivalents: To build on sand.

literal: With a heavy heart.
meaning: To be anxious, depressed, in low spirits: to have a presentiment that something unpleasant or undesirable is about to happen.
equivalents: With a heavy heart

literal: To pull the chestnuts out of the fire.
meaning: To do the hardest and the most painstaking part of some job for someone else’s benefit.
equivalents: To pull the chestnuts out of the fire

literal: To lose one’s head.
meaning: To become flustered, confused, panic stricken; to lose one’s self-control.
equivalents: To lose one’s head/wits; to lose one’s presence of mind.

literal: To strike each other’s hands.
meaning: To confirm an agreement or a business deal; to strike a bargain.
equivalents: To shake hands on it.

literal: To learn something from the first hands.
meaning: To receive information direct from a primary source without intermediaries.
equivalents: At first hand.

literal: To wash one’s hands
meaning: To divest oneself of any further connection with or responsibility for something; to abandon the matter entirely.
equivalents: To wash one’s hands of something.

literal: To make a scene.
meaning: To start a noisy or violent argument, quarrel or scrap with someone, expressing one’s dissatisfaction, irritation, etc.
equivalents: To stage/kick up a row; to make a scene.

literal: To clutch at a straw.
meaning: When in extreme danger, difficulty, etc., to try to seize any chance, however small or useless, of getting out of it.
equivalents: To catch/clutch at a straw

literal: To walk on a brink of an abyss.
meaning: To be in imminent mortal danger; to be on the verge of a disaster.
equivalents: On a brink of a precipice

literal: Over someone’s head.
meaning: To do something without informing one’s immediate superior; to apply to a higher authority by passing an intermediate one.
equivalents: To go over someone’s head

literal: In black on white.
meaning: To declare or state something definitely, clearly, distinctly.
equivalents: In black and white

literal: A devil’s dozen.
meaning: Thirteen.
equivalents: A devil’s/a baker’s dozen

literal: To read between the lines.
meaning: To discern the concealed meaning; to draw conclusions which are not obvious in something said or written.
equivalents: To read between the lines.

literal: Jokes aside.
meaning: Speaking seriously; it’s a serious matter; let’s get down to business.
equivalents: Joking apart/aside; all kidding aside.

literal: You can break your tongue.
meaning: It’s very difficult to pronounce a word or a phrase.
equivalents: You can break /twist your tongue

literal: Clear as day.
meaning: Easy to see or comprehend; quite evident, obvious; as plain or clear as can be.
equivalents: As plain as the nose on your face; as plain as day
